source.query: single leg toe touch muscles worked
source.raw_text:
Single-Leg Toe Touches primarily target the hamstrings, glutes, and core (abs), while improving balance, stability, and hip mobility through a hip-hinge pattern, working muscles dynamically for stretching and strengthening, especially the posterior chain and stabilizers, and enhancing proprioception for better body awareness. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked (Primary & Secondary) 

• Hamstrings: (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus) – Key muscles for stretching and eccentric control. 
• Glutes: (Gluteus Maximus) – Activates to help drive you back up and stabilize the hip. 
• Core: (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis) – Stabilizes the torso and prevents excessive spinal rounding. 
• Calves & Ankles: Act as stabilizers during the single-leg stance. 
• Lower Back: (Spinal Erectors) – Involved in maintaining spinal posture during the hinge. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Starting Position: Stand on one leg, keeping a slight bend in the supporting knee; the other leg is lifted behind you. 
2. The Hinge: Hinge forward at the hip (not by rounding the spine), reaching the opposite hand towards the floor or your standing foot. 
3. Dynamic Stretch: Feel the stretch in the hamstring of the standing leg and the glute/lower back of the lifted leg. 
4. Return: Drive through the glute and hamstring to return to the starting position, squeezing at the top. 
5. Balance Focus: The movement emphasizes controlling the descent and ascent, challenging balance and motor control. [1, 3, 6, 9, 10]  

Benefits 

• Dynamic Warm-Up: Great for preparing for sports and lifting. 
• Improves Balance & Proprioception: Enhances body awareness and joint stability. 
• Strengthens Posterior Chain: Activates hamstrings, glutes, and core. 
• Increases Flexibility: Stretches hamstrings and hips. 
• Injury Prevention: Strengthens stabilizing muscles around the knee, ankle, and hip. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
